title: Psalms Chapter 90 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 90 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 90 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 90.

questions.question: Who is credited as the author of Psalms 90?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:1 identifies the author as Moses, the man of God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:2, how long has God existed?
options: Since the creation of the earth
From the time of the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: From everlasting to everlasting
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:2 states God exists from everlasting to everlasting.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90:4 compare a thousand years to?
options: Yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night
questions.correctAnswer: Yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:4 compares a thousand years to yesterday past and a watch in the night.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:5, what are people compared to when carried away by God like a flood?
questions.correctAnswer: A sleep
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:5 says people are as a sleep when carried away by God like a flood.

questions.question: What happens to grass by evening as described in Psalms 90:6?
options: It is cut down and withers
questions.correctAnswer: It is cut down and withers
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:6 explains that grass is cut down and withers by evening.

questions.question: What causes people to be consumed and troubled according to Psalms 90:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Thine anger and wrath
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:7 states that people are consumed and troubled by God's anger and wrath.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:10, what is the typical lifespan given to man?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy years
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:10 mentions the days of our years as threescore (seventy) years.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90:12 encourages us to number our days so that we may gain wisdom.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:12 teaches us to number our days to apply our hearts to wisdom.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 90:1: 'Lord, thou hast been our _______ place in all generations.'
questions.correctAnswer: dwelling
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:1 states that the Lord has been our dwelling place in all generations.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:14, what does the psalmist ask God to satisfy us with early?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:14 asks God to satisfy us early with His mercy.

questions.question: What is described as 'a tale that is told' in Psalms 90:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Our years
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:9 compares our years to a tale that is told.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90:13 asks the LORD how long He will not repent concerning His servants.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:13 says, 'Return, O LORD, how long? and let it repent thee concerning thy servants.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 90:16 ask God to show to His servants?
questions.correctAnswer: His glory
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:16 requests that God's glory appear to His servants.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:3, what does God say to the children of men?
questions.correctAnswer: Return
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:3 says God turns man to destruction and says, 'Return, ye children of men.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90:17 prays for the work of our hands to be established by God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:17 asks God to establish the work of our hands upon us.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 90 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 90 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by the brevity of life and asks you how to find wisdom in this truth. Based on Psalms 90, what biblical truth would you share?
options: We should number our days to apply our hearts unto wisdom.
Life is eternal and we need not worry about earthly days.
God does not care about the length of our lives.
We should ignore the brevity of life and focus on pleasures.
questions.correctAnswer: We should number our days to apply our hearts unto wisdom.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:12 teaches us to number our days so that we gain wisdom. This is supported by the understanding of life's brevity in verses 4, 5, and 10, which describe how short and fleeting our years are.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90 describe God's eternal nature in relation to creation?
options: God is from everlasting to everlasting, before the mountains and earth were formed.
God was created after the mountains.
God is limited by time like humans.
God only created the earth but not the heavens.
questions.correctAnswer: God is from everlasting to everlasting, before the mountains and earth were formed.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:2 clearly states that God is eternal, existing before the mountains and earth were formed, emphasizing His unchanging and everlasting nature.

questions.question: A believer struggles with the reality of God's anger and asks how to understand it. What biblical help does Psalms 90 provide?
options: God’s anger is powerful and just, but we should seek His mercy and repentance.
God does not get angry at all.
God’s anger is permanent and without hope for forgiveness.
We should ignore God's anger and live as we please.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger is powerful and just, but we should seek His mercy and repentance.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:7-9 and 11 acknowledge God's anger and wrath, but verses 13-14 call for His mercy and repentance, showing that while God’s anger is real, His mercy is also accessible.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90, how should believers respond to the fleeting nature of life in their daily work and service?
options: We should ask God to establish the work of our hands and find lasting purpose.
Our work is meaningless since life is short.
We only work for earthly rewards.
We should avoid work and focus on rest.
questions.correctAnswer: We should ask God to establish the work of our hands and find lasting purpose.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 asks God to establish the work of our hands, implying that despite life’s brevity, our labor can have enduring value when blessed by God.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90 teaches that our secret sins are hidden from God and do not affect our relationship with Him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:8 states that God has set our iniquities and secret sins before Him, indicating that nothing is hidden and all sin affects our standing with God.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90 say about the typical lifespan of humans and the quality of those years?
options: The days of our years are seventy or eighty, but they are often filled with labor and sorrow.
Our years are always full of joy and strength.
Life expectancy is not mentioned in Psalms 90.
questions.correctAnswer: The days of our years are seventy or eighty, but they are often filled with labor and sorrow.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:10 describes the human lifespan as seventy or eighty years, with the additional note that these years may involve labor and sorrow, highlighting life’s challenges.

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by trials and asks how to maintain joy. What does Psalms 90 suggest?
options: God satisfies us early with His mercy so that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.
We should ignore God and find joy in worldly things.
Suffering means God has abandoned us.
Joy is impossible in hard times.
questions.correctAnswer: God satisfies us early with His mercy so that we may rejoice and be glad all our days.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:14 encourages believers to seek God’s mercy early so that they may experience sustained joy despite affliction and hardship.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90 illustrate the human condition in relation to God's justice and mercy?
options: We are consumed by God's anger but can seek His mercy and repentance.
God ignores human sin and is indifferent.
Humans are righteous and do not need mercy.
God's justice is harsh and without mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: We are consumed by God's anger but can seek His mercy and repentance.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-9 show human frailty under God's anger, while verses 13-15 show the call for God’s mercy and repentance, balancing justice with mercy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Let the beauty of the LORD our God be upon us: and establish thou the _______ of our hands upon us; yea, the work of our hands establish thou it.'
questions.correctAnswer: work
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:17 calls for God to establish the work of our hands, emphasizing the desire for God’s blessing on our daily labor and efforts.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90, what analogy is used to describe the fleeting nature of human life?
options: Life is like grass that grows up in the morning and withers in the evening.
Life is like a mountain that stands forever.
Life is like a river that never changes.
Life is like a stone that lasts for ages.
questions.correctAnswer: Life is like grass that grows up in the morning and withers in the evening.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:5-6 compares life to grass that flourishes in the morning and is cut down and withers by evening, illustrating its brevity and fragility.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90 teaches that God’s wrath is unknown and cannot be understood by humans.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:11 asks who knows the power of God’s anger, but it also states that His wrath corresponds to the fear of Him, meaning humans have awareness and should revere God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90 encourage believers to respond when God has afflicted them with trials?
options: Be glad according to the days wherein God has afflicted us and the years of seeing evil.
Deny that any affliction has occurred.
questions.correctAnswer: Be glad according to the days wherein God has afflicted us and the years of seeing evil.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:15 encourages believers to find gladness even in times of affliction and hardship, trusting God’s purposes.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90 teach about God's role as a refuge for His people throughout generations?
options: The Lord has been our dwelling place in all generations.
God only protects the righteous in their own generation.
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord has been our dwelling place in all generations.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:1 states that God has been the dwelling place for His people throughout all generations, emphasizing His faithfulness and protection.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with hidden sin and guilt. What truth from Psalms 90 would you share to encourage confession and humility?
options: God has set our iniquities and secret sins before Him, so we must confess and seek His forgiveness.
Secret sins are invisible to God.
We should hide our sins and avoid confession.
Sin does not affect our relationship with God.
questions.correctAnswer: God has set our iniquities and secret sins before Him, so we must confess and seek His forgiveness.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:8 reminds us that God sees all sin, including secret sins, encouraging believers to humbly confess and seek mercy.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90 portray the passage of time from God's perspective compared to humans?
options: A thousand years to God are like yesterday when it is past.
Time passes at the same rate for God and humans.
God is limited by human years.
God does not perceive time at all.
questions.correctAnswer: A thousand years to God are like yesterday when it is past.
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:4 teaches that God's perception of time is vastly different, with a thousand years being like a day, highlighting His eternal nature.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 90 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 90.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90:2 describe God's existence in relation to creation?
options: God existed from everlasting to everlasting before the earth was formed
God was created after the mountains were formed
God's existence began with the creation of the world
God is limited to the lifespan of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: God existed from everlasting to everlasting before the earth was formed
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:2 states that God is eternal, existing 'even from everlasting to everlasting' before the mountains and earth were created, emphasizing His timeless nature.

questions.question: What literary device is used in Psalms 90:4 when it compares a thousand years to a day and a watch in the night?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:4 uses similes by directly comparing a thousand years to 'yesterday when it is past' and 'a watch in the night', illustrating God's perception of time.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:10, what is the typical human lifespan described as?
questions.correctAnswer: Threescore years and ten
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:10 states that the days of our years are 'threescore years and ten' (70 years), with some reaching 80 but accompanied by labor and sorrow.

questions.question: What does Moses ask God to teach in Psalms 90:12?
questions.correctAnswer: To number our days
questions.explanation: In Psalms 90:12, Moses prays for wisdom to understand the brevity of life by learning to number our days, so we may gain a wise heart.

questions.question: Psalms 90:1 refers to God as our ______________ in all generations.
questions.correctAnswer: Dwelling place
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:1 calls the Lord 'our dwelling place in all generations,' indicating God's eternal refuge and presence with His people.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 90 reflects the ancient Near Eastern understanding of human mortality?
options: The fleeting nature of human life like grass
questions.correctAnswer: The fleeting nature of human life like grass
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:5-6 uses imagery of grass that flourishes in the morning and withers by evening, reflecting the ANE view of human life’s transience.

questions.question: Psalms 90:7 says 'For we are consumed by thine anger.' This reflects which theological concept common in the Old Testament?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment for sin
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the Old Testament concept that God's anger results in judgment upon human sinfulness, emphasizing accountability.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 90:17 prays for God to establish the work of human hands upon us.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:17 explicitly requests God to 'establish thou the work of our hands,' asking for divine blessing on human endeavors.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Return, O LORD, how long?' in Psalms 90:13 in the context of Israel's history?
options: A plea for restoration after exile
A call for new laws to be given
questions.correctAnswer: A plea for restoration after exile
questions.explanation: The plea in Psalms 90:13 likely reflects Israel’s longing for God's return and mercy during or after times of judgment, such as the Babylonian exile.

questions.question: In Psalms 90:9, what metaphor is used to describe the span of human life?
questions.correctAnswer: A tale that is told
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:9 compares human life to 'a tale that is told,' highlighting its brevity and the passing nature of years.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is attributed as the author of Psalms 90?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: The superscription of Psalms 90 identifies Moses as the author, describing him as 'the man of God.'

questions.question: How does Psalms 90:8 reveal God's knowledge of human sin?
options: God sets our iniquities before Him and sees our secret sins in His light
God ignores hidden sins and only judges public ones
God only knows sins that are confessed
God is unaware of secret sins
questions.correctAnswer: God sets our iniquities before Him and sees our secret sins in His light
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:8 states that God has placed our iniquities before Him and sees even our secret sins clearly, showing divine omniscience.

questions.question: In the structure of Psalms 90, which poetic device is primarily used to emphasize the contrast between God's eternity and human mortality?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The Psalm employs parallelism, notably contrasting God's eternal nature with the fleeting human life, a common Hebrew poetic device.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage echoes the theme of numbering our days for wisdom as found in Psalms 90:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Ephesians 5:15-16
questions.explanation: Ephesians 5:15-16 urges believers to walk carefully and make the best use of time, reflecting the wisdom sought in Psalms 90:12.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'as a watch in the night' in Psalms 90:4 culturally refer to?
options: A period of a few hours during the night when guards kept watch
The dawn of a new day
questions.correctAnswer: A period of a few hours during the night when guards kept watch
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern culture, 'a watch in the night' referred to a division of the night watched by guards, symbolizing a brief span of time.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 90 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 90 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:2, how is God's existence described in relation to creation?
options: God existed from everlasting to everlasting before the earth was formed
God was created after the mountains were brought forth
God is limited by the age of the world
God and the world were created simultaneously
questions.correctAnswer: God existed from everlasting to everlasting before the earth was formed
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:2 states that before the mountains or the earth existed, God was already present from everlasting to everlasting, affirming His eternal nature. This is consistent with John 1:1-3, Colossians 1:16-17, Revelation 1:8, and Hebrews 13:8 which affirm God's eternal and unchanging existence.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90:4 teach about God's perception of time?
options: A thousand years are like a day and a watch in the night to God
God experiences time exactly as humans do
Time is irrelevant to God because He doesn't exist
God's time is slower than human time
questions.correctAnswer: A thousand years are like a day and a watch in the night to God
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:4 reveals that God's perspective on time is transcendent; a thousand years are like a single day or a brief night watch to Him. This theological truth is echoed in 2 Peter 3:8, Isaiah 57:15, and Psalm 102:25-27, emphasizing God's eternality and transcendence over time.

questions.question: What does Psalm 90 say is the typical human lifespan?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy to eighty years
questions.explanation: Psalm 90:10 states that human life spans seventy years, or eighty if one is strong, but even then it is marked by labor and sorrow. This reflects the biblical view of human mortality found also in Job 14:5, Ecclesiastes 3:1-2, and James 4:14.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'number our days' in Psalms 90:12?
options: To gain wisdom and live with a heart of understanding
To count days for a calendar
To ignore the brevity of life
questions.correctAnswer: To gain wisdom and live with a heart of understanding
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:12 teaches that recognizing the brevity of life should lead to wisdom and thoughtful living. This is consistent with Proverbs 90:12 (same verse), Ecclesiastes 7:2-4, James 1:5, and Colossians 1:9 emphasizing the importance of wisdom in the fear of the Lord.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:7-8, what causes human trouble and consumption?
options: God’s anger and wrath over iniquities
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger and wrath over iniquities
questions.explanation: These verses attribute human suffering and trouble to God's righteous anger because of human sinfulness. This aligns with Isaiah 59:2, Romans 1:18, Nahum 1:2-3, and Hebrews 10:31 showing God's wrath against sin.

questions.question: Psalms 90:1 describes God as what for all generations?
questions.correctAnswer: Our dwelling place
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:1 calls God 'our dwelling place' across all generations, indicating His protective presence and refuge. This theme is echoed in Psalm 91:1, Isaiah 32:2, John 14:2-3, and Hebrews 13:5 emphasizing God as refuge and constant presence.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90:3 mean by 'Thou turnest man to destruction'?
options: God causes humans to return to dust due to mortality
questions.correctAnswer: God causes humans to return to dust due to mortality
questions.explanation: The verse highlights human mortality and that God causes man to return to dust, a concept supported by Genesis 3:19, Ecclesiastes 12:7, Hebrews 9:27, and Job 34:14-15 emphasizing death as part of human condition under God's sovereignty.

questions.question: What is the metaphor used in Psalms 90:5-6 to describe the fleeting nature of human life?
options: Grass that flourishes in the morning and withers in the evening
A mighty tree that stands forever
A stone that lasts for centuries
A river that never runs dry
questions.correctAnswer: Grass that flourishes in the morning and withers in the evening
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:5-6 uses the metaphor of grass that grows and withers in one day to illustrate the brevity and frailty of life. This is confirmed by Isaiah 40:6-8, James 1:10-11, 1 Peter 1:24, and Matthew 6:30 emphasizing human life's transient nature.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:9, how are human years described?
options: As a tale that is told
questions.correctAnswer: As a tale that is told
questions.explanation: Verse 9 likens human years to a story or tale told, emphasizing their fleeting and ephemeral nature. This metaphor aligns with Job 7:6, Ecclesiastes 1:9, Psalm 39:4-5, and James 4:14 which acknowledge human life's brevity and transience.

questions.question: What petition does the psalmist make to God in Psalms 90:13?
options: Return, O LORD, and have compassion on your servants
questions.correctAnswer: Return, O LORD, and have compassion on your servants
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:13 is a plea for God's compassion and mercy to return to His people. This request for divine mercy is a recurring biblical theme seen in Jeremiah 14:7, Lamentations 5:21, 2 Chronicles 7:14, and Luke 18:13.

questions.question: How does Psalms 90:14 describe the desired effect of God's mercy on the psalmist?
options: It satisfies early so that we may rejoice all our days
It hides us from the world
questions.correctAnswer: It satisfies early so that we may rejoice all our days
questions.explanation: Verse 14 expresses a longing for God's mercy to satisfy and bring joy throughout life, reflecting God's grace that produces gladness as seen in Psalm 103:2-4, Isaiah 55:1-3, John 6:35, and Romans 15:13.

questions.question: What does Psalms 90:16 request to be revealed to God's servants and their children?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s work and glory
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks for God's deeds and glory to be made visible to believers and future generations, a biblical theme related to God's revelation in Exodus 33:18-23, Isaiah 60:1-3, Matthew 5:16, and Revelation 21:23.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God being described as 'our dwelling place' in Psalms 90:1?
options: God is our refuge and safe haven throughout all generations
God is distant and uninvolved in human affairs
God is an idol made by human hands
God changes His nature according to generations
questions.correctAnswer: God is our refuge and safe haven throughout all generations
questions.explanation: Calling God 'our dwelling place' indicates His role as a refuge and protector, consistent with Psalm 46:1, Deuteronomy 33:27, John 14:2-3, and Hebrews 6:18 emphasizing God's protective presence for His people.

questions.question: According to Psalms 90:17, what is the psalmist’s request regarding the work of their hands?
options: That God establishes and blesses the work of our hands
That our work be judged by others
questions.correctAnswer: That God establishes and blesses the work of our hands
questions.explanation: The verse petitions God to bless and establish human labor, reflecting a biblical principle in Proverbs 16:3, Psalm 1:3, Colossians 3:23-24, and Ecclesiastes 3:13 about God's sovereign blessing on human endeavors.

questions.question: In Psalms 90:11, what is said about the knowledge of God's anger?
options: No one fully knows the extent of God’s anger
questions.correctAnswer: No one fully knows the extent of God’s anger
questions.explanation: Psalms 90:11 highlights the mystery and fear surrounding God's wrath, consistent with Nahum 1:6, Romans 11:22, Hebrews 10:31, and Revelation 6:16-17 which describe God’s wrath as fearful and powerful beyond human comprehension.
